content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B {B} for this game. Here's why:

1. In any given round, choosing B gives me a guaranteed payoff of 40$, which is better than the worst-case scenario of earning 0$ with choice R if my opponent chooses R.

2. When I choose B and my opponent chooses R, I get a higher payoff (35$) compared to when they choose B (40$). Since I don't know their strategy, I assume they will be more likely to pick R since it gives them a higher payoff in this scenario.

3. The game has 75 rounds. Over the long term, my expected payoff with choice B is higher because I get the guaranteed 40$ every round, while with choice R, there are fewer opportunities for getting the 45$. Moreover, since I expect my opponent to choose R more often (due to its higher payoff in the event they guess my choice incorrectly), there will be many rounds where I get a 35$ payout instead of the 0$ with choice R.

So, based on these reasons, I would choose B {B} for this game.

Over the long term, I expect to have a higher expected payoff by consistently choosing B.

I will choose R {R} for the next round, as my strategy is to deviate from my previous choice of B when both players have chosen the same action in the previous round. By doing this, I create an opportunity for myself to get the higher payoff (45$) if my opponent stays with their choice of B in the following rounds while I switch to R.

However, since I cannot predict my opponent's response, there is a chance that they may also deviate and choose R as well. If this happens, both players will get 0$ in the next round, but I would expect the pattern of switching choices to continue in subsequent rounds based on our new strategy.

Overall, while it's difficult to say for certain which strategy is optimal without knowing my opponent's behavior, deviating from B when my opponent also chooses B seems like a reasonable approach to potentially increase my payoff in the long term.
